title: After creating this class you can use the
<layout>
c
in your layout file to enable databinding for that layout like this:

inline_content.Text: After creating this class you can use the
in your layout file to enable databinding for that layout like this:

title:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">

    <data>
        <variable
            name="item"
            type="ItemModel" />
    </data>

    <LinearLayout
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="match_parent">

        <TextView
            android:layout_width="wrap_content"
            android:layout_height="match_parent"
            android:text="@{item.itemLabel}" />
    </LinearLayout>
</layout>

content_resolved.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<layout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android">

    <data>
        <variable
            name="item"
            type="ItemModel" />
    </data>

    <LinearLayout
        android:layout_width="match_parent"
        android:layout_height="match_parent">

        <TextView
            android:layout_width="wrap_content"
            android:layout_height="match_parent"
            android:text="@{item.itemLabel}" />
    </LinearLayout>
</layout>

title: By default, Android Data Binding library generates a
ViewDataBinding
c
class based on the layout file name, converting it to Pascal case and suffixing “Binding” to it. For this example it would be
MyItemBinding
c
for the layout file
my_item.xml
c
. That Binding class would also have a setter method to set the object defined as data in the layout file(
ItemModel
c
for this example).
